abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcomes are rated as
            satisfactory, sustainability is highly likely, and
            institutional development impacts is substantial, and there
            are satisfactory ratings for both the Bank and Borrower
            performances. Lessons are as follows. The project's
            significant implementation delay was, by and large, caused
            by insufficient preparation time, and inadequate capacity
            building and training prior to project implementation. This
            reinforces the need to assess local capacities and provide
            training as needed, particularly in procurement, financial
            management, and reporting requirements. In addition, the
            inadequacy of project monitoring and evaluation (M&E)
            indicators, as a management tool for both the Borrower and
            Bank, suggests the development of relevant operational
            M&E indicators at the early stages, i.e., project
            design. While project sustainability is highly likely, the
            decentralized implementation process was difficult; instead
            a strong interagency coordination would have further
            benefited success. Finally, lessons reinforce the benefits
            of a simple, clear project design, particularly so in the
            absence of a strong capacity by the implementing agency. And
            a simple project design would have also reduced the need for
            additional consulting funds to properly supervise all
            aspects of the project.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Sector Loan Project for
            Tunisia has four objectives: 1) improving the
            macroefficiency of public investments; 2) improving the
            microefficiency of operations through management reforms; 3)
            enhancing the financial sustainability of publicly supported
            operations by introducing policy measures for cost control;
            and 4) reinforcing the quality of services through improved
            case management and staff training. The project has three
            components. The first facilitates sector reforms and key
            actions by defining basic specialties in regional hospitals,
            which are enabled to use available resources more
            effectively; and redefines central and regional authority
            functions and powers; and links these entities with health
            care providers in the public and private sectors. The second
            upgrades regional hospitals to improve their function of
            initial referral and their provision of specialized care for
            their communities; strengthens national medical emergency
            services; and develops and implements the national health
            information system. The third improves the capacity of the
            health ministry for planning, policy analysis, and financial
            management; and assists in establishing national health
            accounts and in improving the ministry's reporting and
            financial management system.
